review.title: A Novel Approach for Single Gene Selection Using Clustering and Dimensionality Reduction
review.abstract: We extend the standard rough set-based approach to deal with huge amounts of numeric attributes versus small amount of available objects. Here, a novel approach of clustering along with dimensionality reduction; Hybrid Fuzzy C Means-Quick Reduct (FCMQR) algorithm is proposed for single gene selection. Gene selection is a process to select genes which are more informative. It is one of the important steps in knowledge discovery. The problem is that all genes are not important in gene expression data. Some of the genes may be redundant, and others may be irrelevant and noisy. In this study, the entire dataset is divided in proper grouping of similar genes by applying Fuzzy C Means (FCM) algorithm. A high class discriminated genes has been selected based on their degree of dependence by applying Quick Reduct algorithm based on Rough Set Theory to all the resultant clusters. Average Correlation Value (ACV) is calculated for the high class discriminated genes. The clusters which have the ACV value a s 1 is determined as significant clusters, whose classification accuracy will be equal or high when comparing to the accuracy of the entire dataset. The proposed algorithm is evaluated using WEKA classifiers and compared. Finally, experimental results related to the leukemia cancer data confirm that our approach is quite promising, though it surely requires further research.
histories: 6 pages, 4 figures. arXiv admin note: text overlap witharXiv:1306.1323

metadata.title: A Novel Approach for Single Gene Selection Using Clustering and Dimensionality Reduction

sections.text: The hybrid Fuzzy C Means-Quick Reduct (FCMQR) algorithm is proposed for the selection of individual genes. Gene selection is a process for selecting genes that are more informative. It is one of the important steps in the discovery of knowledge. The problem is that all genes do not play a role in the gene expression data. Some of the genes may be redundant, and others may be irrelevant and noisy. In this study, the entire data set is divided into the correct grouping of similar genes using the Fuzzy C Means (FCM) algorithm. High-class discriminated genes were selected based on their dependence grade e by applying the Quick Reduct algorithm to all resulting clusters. The average correlation value (ACV) is calculated for f or the high-class discriminated genes. The clusters that have the ACV value a s 1 are determined as signified clusters.

sections.heading: 2.1 Fuzzy C-Means Clustering
sections.text: Fuzzy C-Means (FCM) is a method of clustering that allows a piece of data to belong to two or more clusters [2], [14]. This method (developed by Dunn in 1973 and improved by Bezdek in 1981) is commonly used in pattern recognition, the Fuzzy C-Means algorithm is given below: Algorithm 1: Fuzzy C-Means cluster algorithm [14] Step-1: Random initialization of the member matrix using this equation, Step-3: Calculation of centrification using the equation, Step-2: Calculation of centrification using centrification, Step-1: () () Step-3: Calculation of centrification using centrification 1 (2) (2) is centrification using centrification 1 (1) (2) (2).

sections.heading: 2.2 K-Means Discretization
sections.text: Given that most experimental data is continuous and not discrete, the discretization of continuous attributes is an important issue. The goal of discretization is to reduce the number of possible values that a continuous attribute takes by dividing them into a number of intervals. K-Means is used in this essay, where in gene expression data each gene attribute is clustered with K-Means and the attribute values are replaced by cluster labels, which will act as discrete values for the gene expression data set.

sections.heading: 2.3 Quick Reduct Algorithm
sections.text: Rough set theory (Pawlak, 1991) is a formal mathematical tool that can be applied to reduce the dimensionality of the dataset. The method of reducing attributes removes redundant input attributes from the dataset of discrete values while ensuring that no information is lost. Reduction of attributes is achieved by comparing equivalence relationships generated by attribute sets. Attributes are removed so that the reduced set of attributes provides the same quality of classification as the original. A reduction is defined as a subset R of the conditional attribute set C, so that the quantitative reduction of attributes in a given dataset can have many attribute sets, so that the set R of all reductions is defined as: Rall = [X | X'C, γX's = categorical reduction of attributes in a minimum of attributes C.

sections.heading: 2.4 Average Correlation Value
sections.text: The average correlation value is used to evaluate the homogeneity of a cluster. Matrix A = (Aij) has the ACV, which is defined by the following function: ACV (A) = = 1 2 − = 1 = 1 (3) Where C _ rowij - the correlation coefficient is between rows i and j, C _ colpq is the correlation coefficient between columns p and q, ACV 1 approaches a significant cluster. Such a technique can be found in [12].

sections.heading: 3 HYBRID FUZZY C-MEAN-QUICKREDUCT (FCMQR) ALGORITHM
sections.text: The proposed FCMQR algorithm consists of three steps: (i) grouping of similar genes, (ii) feature selection from the group, (iii) finding ACV and selection of representative characteristics. The purpose of the algorithm is to identify a subset of characteristics R = RG1, RG2,..., RGBs from the subset G = G1, G2,..., Gn, where n is the dimension of gene characteristics vectors and r < n is the number of selected characteristics that comprise ACV = 1. (i) The characteristics Gbest are contained in the subset R, if this Gbest, the subset R, which indicates the subset R.

sections.heading: 4 EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.1 Data Set
sections.text: We use leukemia data sets available on the website: http: / / datam.i2r.a-star.edu.sg / datasets / krbd / [15]. Our initial leukemia data set consisted of 38 bone marrow samples (27 ALL, 11 AML) collected at the time of diagnosis from acute leukemia patients. RNA produced from mononuclear bone marrow cells was hybridized to high density oligonucleotide microarrays produced by Affymetrix containing probes over 7129 from 6817 human genes [18].

sections.heading: 4.2 Cluster Analysis and Gene Selection
sections.text: Gene clustering identifies group of genes that exhibit similar expression profiles in the samples. Fuzzy C-Means clustering is used to identify the similar characteristics of genes GCi clusters. Prior to clustering, must specify the number of clusters. The optimal number of clusters is difficult to determine because it will depend on different groups of genes in the study. In this study, the number of clusters is chosen to be five and seven (k = 5, 7), then leukemia data set will share k number of groups using Fuzzy C-Means clustering techniques. According to clustering, properties or genes are selected from a similar GCi cluster. Rough Quick Reduct was used as a feature selection method. The data, which are determined by coarse genes are mainly organized in the form of decision tables. A decision table can be represented as S = (U = GCi U = GCi U D), where U is the set of samples in clusters GCCi class 2.

sections.heading: 5 WEKA CLASSIFICATION
sections.text: The classification tool WEKA [1], [11], [13] is open source Java-based machine learning = 779 genes. It combines many machine learning algorithms and tools under a common framework. WEKA is a well-known package of data mining tools that provides a variety of well-known, well-maintained classification algorithms. This allows us to experiment quickly and easily with different types of classifiers. # Some of the classification tools we use in our experiment # # # # # 5 # are bayes.NaiveBayes, trees.J48, rules.2, Denotes classification table and lazy.K-Star.Fig.2, Denotes classification accuracy for leukemia data # # # # 5 #.We have selected thirteen genes from whole genes by applying Quick Reduct # 232, genes containing ACV = 1, that five genes with ACV = 5 GRV that are best.

sections.heading: 5.1 Comparison of Classification Results
sections.text: The leukemia dataset has been well studied by many researchers [3], [4], [5], [6], [8], [9], [10] Although there are some reports of the use of a single gene to distinguish AML from ALL, the majority of researchers perform the classification with more than one gene, even with dozens or hundreds. In [15], the authors present the classification results of 31 out of 34 samples correctly classified with a common gene (# 4847): X.Wang & O.Gotoh, we correctly classify 33 out of 34 samples using a selected gene (# 3252). Classification accuracy for existing and proposed selected individual genes presented in Table 7.TABLE 7COMPARISON BEETWEEN EXISTING AND PROPOSED METHODClassified Existing Method Gene # 4847 Proposed FCMQR Gene # 3252Naïve 91,1765 787 Table 855,85175,865 Leukemia 855,865

sections.heading: 6 CONCLUSION
sections.text: A novel approach was proposed that combines clustering and coarse-set attribute reduction (FCMQR) methods for gene expression data, selecting informative genes based on their classification accuracy, investigating and successfully implementing fuzzy-C-Means clustering, rough quick reduction, and average correlation value methods for gene selection, and providing sparse and interpretable classification accuracy compared to other gene selection methods for leukemia gene expression data. Classification accuracy of genes was performed using the WEKA classifier.

In such a scenario, dimensionality reduction is crucial in order to overcome the curse of dimensionality [7],[11]and allow for meaningful data analysis.
